title: Why is riot so sensitive?
body: Why is the LOL community so sensitive? 2 permabans for calling someone out for trolling. If someone is deliberately throwing the game and being a troll, you should be allowed to say whatever you want. Stop being such snowflakes and just play the game.

So calling someone out for "running it down" isn't justified, and the fact they aren't banned because riot doesn't develop their banning system,  but you are is? (when you aren't racists/homophobic or just sworn worst being "f*ck"). Food for thought. Not to mention, riot never enforces the "mute" button or the "word filter", something people never seem to make use of.

No, it's the insecure jerks who are snowflakes that is incapable of following one simple rule, but too sensitive to hold back their anger and lashes out just to get banned. Again.

And you're calling them the decent players' snowflakes.

Logic.

Calling an 0/15 botlane "bad" isn't exactly "getting angry" or "lashing out", but it will still get you punished/banned. Who do you think is really being sensitive in that situation, where someone having an 0/15 score is objectively bad.

How exactly do you define "objectively bad"? We know now already that assists clearly don't factor into that, but I'd love to know the exact procedure with which you (objectively) determine somebody's bad-ness.
Can you think of a situation where an 0/15 ADC is not bad?
Irrelevant. You said it was a matter of objectivity, not that it was something multiple people can agree on.
So what are you actually trying to argue? That nobody can be considered "bad" in a game?

Considered? What's to consider, I thought it was an objective attribute?

What I am arguing is that deliberately or inadvertently confusing "objective" and "subjective" makes any discussion that follows absolutely pointless. You are essentially implying right from the beginning that you consider your opinion to be fact.
An ADC going 0/15 in a Ranked game is objectively bad.

Again: What's the procedure then, by which one can objectively determine that this is bad? What is even the definition of being bad?

If it's not just your opinion, show me a rigorous proof that a 0/15 ADC is bad.
Edit: Or some empiric evidence based on a scientific model/definition of bad-ness, of course.
Unfortunately I do not have access to Riots data, so I cannot actually tell you how often 0/15 ADCs win in Ranked.

Okay, let' ignore for a second that this implies that you don't even **know** whether a 0/15 ADC is bad. Let's say you have that information.

Let's assume for a second that you have this information. 0/15 ADCs have on average a winrate of x%.
How do you use that information to determine whether **this** ADC in particular is bad?
You can always tell just by watching or seeing the game. A Vayne consistently tumbling into 3+ members of the enemy team until they are 0/15, for example.

And I am asking you **how** you can tell. Most people can tell whether something tastes good or bad **to them**. That doesn't mean it's not a matter of opinion.

Honestly, I'm starting to suspect you simply do not understand what the word "objective" means.

You can tell by watching them play. As soon as I see someone outside of the Player Behavior board claim that an ADC going 0/15 is not bad, I'll get back to you.

Even if that was true (And it isn't automatically so; sometimes the circumstances are simply against you), it still doesn't make that punishable. Everyone has bad games. And telling him that he is bad won't make him play any better; often the opposite is true: Telling him he is bad will result in him playing even worse since it will annoy him/make him angry and make him play worse. Thus the people lashing out at him should not do so.

(And yes, it is quite difficult to talk to a person whom you think is 'bad' without it being understood as negative, so often it is better to stay silent. Silence is golden, after all.)

Wow this chat really took off. My point obviously wasn't taken. Let me give an example. 
If you were to become a professional sports athlete (IE. MLB, NFL, NHL) and went out to play. During the game, you decided to throw pitches all over the place on purpose, tackle your own teammates or score on your own goal. Do you think anybody would object to you calling your teammate (the one doing these things) a fkng idiot? No, you would receive never ending support from your team and the fans. Even the opposing team would find that player to be disrespectful and also agree with the "fking idiot" statement. Only the league community cries over these type of things. No other platform does this kind of pampering and coddling.
Because Riot supports, defends and influences sensitivity
